content: The environmental impacts of human activity, including pollution, habitat destruction, and greenhouse gas emissions, have raised concerns. Buildings, such as residential, commercial, and government structures, are a significant part of the nation's infrastructure and are increasingly scrutinized for their environmental effects. Buildings, including residential, commercial, government, schools, and hospitals, are a major component of the nation's infrastructure. Their construction, operation, and demolition have significant environmental impacts, consuming resources like electricity, water, and construction materials while generating waste throughout their lifecycle. Buildings have significant environmental impacts due to their supply chains, manufacturing processes, and waste streams. They account for 40% of energy consumption in the US, produce 40% of greenhouse gas emissions, and cost consumers over $430 billion annually in energy bills. Additionally, buildings' locations and interactions with the environment affect ecological and human health impacts, particularly in stormwater management. Buildings' locations and interactions with the environment influence stormwater management and associated health and environmental impacts. Proximity to public transportation affects energy required for commuting. Building features impact indoor air quality, affecting occupant health and productivity. Green building addresses indoor air quality issues in buildings, aiming to reduce pollutants that can lead to "sick building syndrome." It transforms the design, construction, operation, and demolition of buildings, gaining significant interest since the 1990s. Green building has gained substantial interest since the 1990s, evolving into a respected approach to building with various stakeholders involved. This report discusses the concept of green building, federal policies, programs, and associated issues. The concept of green building, federal policies, programs, and associated issues are discussed. Green building emerged in the 1990s and addresses environmental impacts. Major statutory and executive authorities and federal agency programs are involved in promoting environmentally sensitive building practices. The modern practice of green building emerged in the 1990s with the formation of organizations like the Committee on the Environment and the U.S. Green Building Council. The concept has expanded to encompass environmentally conscious design principles and strategies for reducing environmental impact. The concept of green building has evolved to include environmentally conscious design principles and strategies to reduce the harmful impacts of the built environment. There is no single definition, with efforts existing along a design and performance continuum. Some practices are indistinguishable from standard building, while others aim to greatly reduce environmental impacts. Practices that use the term "green" purely for marketing purposes are sometimes referred to as "greenwashing." Some practitioners aim to provide buildings with greatly reduced environmental impacts, such as zero-impact and minus-impact buildings. Green building is an integrated approach that significantly reduces the environmental footprint of buildings. Green building is an integrated approach that significantly reduces the environmental footprint of buildings by considering multiple factors, not limited to just energy consumption. It is a relative concept, with green buildings being greener than average and can be applied to any class of building. The green building approach involves integration across multiple factors and can be applied to any type of building. Green builders aim to improve environmental performance through various techniques, such as using energy-efficient systems and designing features to influence occupant behavior. Decision-making on which techniques to use is typically done during the design and planning stages. Green building techniques are often decided during the design phase and can impact a building's environmental footprint. The term green building is used interchangeably with sustainable building, although they may not be exactly synonymous. Sustainable building is sometimes considered a form of green building. Sustainable building, also known as green building, aims to maintain small environmental footprints to support future human activity and ecosystem functioning. High-performance building, another term used interchangeably with green building, includes factors like security in addition to environmental considerations. Federal statutory definitions emphasize the integration and optimization of all major high-performance building attributes. High-performance buildings integrate and optimize various attributes such as energy efficiency, durability, occupant productivity, safety, security, accessibility, cost-benefit, sustainability, and functionality. Additional objectives like aesthetics and historical preservation may also be considered in their design. The Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 refined the concept of high-performance green buildings by establishing a detailed definition. Green building focuses on elements like energy, water, materials, waste, health, and siting with respect to transportation, ecology, and smart considerations. High-performance green buildings focus on elements like energy, water, materials, waste, health, siting with respect to transportation, ecology, and smart growth. Siting has gained prominence in recent years, considering the built environment beyond the building itself. Objectives for high-performance buildings may also include serviceability, productivity, functionality, disaster resilience, and climate resilience. The objectives for high-performance buildings include disaster and climate resilience, which have become more important due to natural disasters like Hurricanes Katrina and Sandy, and the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear meltdown. A reduced energy footprint is a key focus, achieved through energy efficiency, conservation, and the use of alternative energy sources like solar or geothermal power. Energy storage technologies are also utilized in combination with on-site renewable energy. The importance of energy efficiency in buildings is highlighted through the use of alternative, renewable sources like solar or geothermal power, energy storage technologies, and participation in smart-grid innovations. Energy savings potential is higher for buildings compared to transportation and industry, as stated in reports by the National Academies and the Department of Energy. In a 2015 report, the Department of Energy estimated that buildings using the best energy efficiency technologies would consume about half as much energy as current buildings. Federal law mandates energy use reductions in federal buildings, with a 22% decline in energy intensity from 2003 to 2015. Despite this, 2015 consumption exceeded the federal goal, highlighting the misconception that energy is the sole focus of green building. While energy is important in green building, it should not be the sole focus. Water management in buildings can also provide cost savings and aid in the conservation of water resources, especially in arid areas. This can be achieved through measures like reduced-flow plumbing fixtures and recycling of wastewater. Water management in buildings involves reductions through measures like reduced-flow plumbing fixtures, wastewater recycling, and landscaping to reduce irrigation needs. It also includes managing rain, on-site water, and run-off. Low-impact development aims to mimic natural water handling processes through techniques like using porous materials, green roofs, and holding ponds. Water management in buildings includes reducing impervious surfaces through landscaping, porous materials, and green roofs, as well as using holding ponds, swales, rain gardens, and similar measures. These techniques, collectively known as green infrastructure, help manage water effectively. The choice and use of materials in construction and operations significantly impact a building's environmental footprint, affecting resource depletion, pollution, embodied energy, and health. Opting for environmentally preferable or green-labelled products with recycled content can reduce the environmental impact. Environmentally preferable or green-labelled products can reduce the impact of resource depletion, pollution, embodied energy, and health risks. These materials may have recycled content, be made from renewable resources, or use processes with low energy and pollutant levels. There is debate on what defines environmentally preferable materials due to inconsistent vocabulary and measurement methodologies. The lack of consistent vocabulary and measurement methodologies in describing sustainability attributes of materials can make it challenging to determine their preference. Waste reduction efforts in building projects can include source reduction, reuse, recycling, and waste-to-energy to mitigate environmental impacts. Efficient material use and recycling can help reduce waste from standard demolition and construction processes. Efficient material use and recycling in building projects can reduce waste from demolition and construction processes. Landscaping can also play a role in waste reduction by recycling lawn clippings through mulching and composting. High-efficiency boilers and furnaces can decrease atmospheric pollutants. Operational solid waste like paper and food can be recycled to lessen environmental impact. Various factors can affect the health impacts of buildings, including indoor air pollutants like mold and radon. The health impacts of buildings are influenced by various factors, with indoor air quality (IAQ) being a significant concern. Maintaining high IAQ involves adequate ventilation, air filtration, and using materials free of toxic substances. Overall indoor environmental quality (IEQ) includes factors like lighting, climate control, acoustics, and ergonomic design. The indoor environmental quality (IEQ) of a building is influenced by factors such as lighting, climate control, acoustics, and ergonomic design. Site selection and building orientation can also impact the environmental footprint and ecological sensitivity of the area. The ecological sensitivity of potential building sites is crucial to minimize adverse impacts on ecological services and native species. Factors like building orientation, proximity to trees, and climate-related risks should be considered in siting decisions, especially in coastal areas. Productivity and utility are essential considerations for a building's worth, regardless of its environmental footprint. Green building's importance lies in its utility and productivity for occupants, with studies showing that Indoor Environmental Quality (IEQ) affects worker comfort and productivity. While green buildings can enhance productivity, trade-offs between serviceability and other elements like acoustic performance may occur. Practices for resilience include resistant construction. Approaches to resilience in building design include resistant construction, locating critical components away from flood waters, on-site power generation, rainwater harvesting, and water recycling. Climate-resilient design focuses on preparing for severe weather events and climate change to ensure assets can withstand disruptions. Green building focuses on integration across elements and stages to improve performance and minimize environmental impacts throughout the building's lifecycle. This approach allows for better assessment of environmental impact, balance among competing goals, and explicit examination of the whole building design. The integration of different elements in green building allows for a comprehensive assessment of environmental impact and balance among goals. Balancing energy efficiency and health may require compromises or technologies like active ventilation. A green building approach forces an examination of how actions impact each element to achieve overall optimization. A focus on optimizing green building practices by considering how actions affect different elements, even if only one factor can be addressed in some cases. In the building sector, formal systems and tools have been developed to assess whether construction projects meet green and sustainable criteria. These tools include rating systems, certifications, standards, and codes, but determining a building's sustainability is complex with no simple metric. Professional organizations in the 1990s developed rating and certification systems to address this issue. Rating and certification systems were developed in the 1990s by professional organizations in the building sector to standardize and define green building practices. These systems, such as LEED, assign points to buildings for meeting green design criteria, resulting in an overall score. Rating systems assign points to buildings for meeting green design criteria, resulting in an overall score and certification validates that a building meets specified design or performance requirements. Independent third parties conduct assessments and award certifications to ensure objectivity. LEED, developed by the USGBC in 1998, is a widely recognized green building certification system in the US. Over 37,300 commercial buildings have been LEED certified as of April 2017. The number of LEED certifications has increased annually since 2000, with over 37,300 commercial buildings certified worldwide as of April 2017. USGBC offers certifications for various building categories and focuses on six green building elements. LEED certification involves the design, construction, and maintenance of buildings with a five-year recertification cycle. It focuses on six green building elements and includes credit categories for innovation and regional priority. Buildings must meet mandatory requirements and earn a designated number of points to be certified. The LEED rating system involves meeting basic requirements and earning points for certification levels: Certified, Silver, Gold, or Platinum. It allows for simple compliance assessment and integrated consideration of green building elements. LEED v4, released in 2013, is the most recent version. Other certification systems in the US include The Building Research Establishment. The LEED v4 rating system, released in 2013, is the most recent version. Other certification systems in the US include the BREEAM In-Use system, which is an online rating system for existing commercial building performance with no prerequisites. BREEAM In-Use is an online rating system for existing buildings with no prerequisites. Ratings range from Acceptable to Outstanding, based on performance in nine impact categories. Certifications must be renewed annually. Green Globes, based on BREEAM, awards between one and four Globes. Green Globes, a rating system by the Green Building Initiative, is based on BREEAM and awards between one and four Globes based on points earned across six elements. Certification is solely based on points earned with no mandatory provisions. The International Living Future Institute's Living Building Challenge offers three certifications: Living Building Certification, Petal Certification, and Zero Energy Building Certification. Criteria for certification fall into seven performance areas, referred to as "Petals": place, water, energy, health and happiness, materials, equity, and beauty. Living Building Certification requires compliance in all seven areas, Petal Certification requires compliance in at least three areas including water, energy, or materials, and Zero Energy Certification requires a building to generate all its energy needs on site. The Living Building Challenge offers three certifications: Living Building Certification, Petal Certification, and Zero Energy Building Certification. Different green building ratings systems emphasize various aspects, with suitability depending on local conditions and priorities. Several federal statutes and policies impose green building requirements on federal offices and agencies, with some agencies using third-party green building certification systems since the late 1990s. These systems have influenced building codes and standards, with certification being voluntary compared to mandatory building codes. Building codes are mandatory regulations that specify minimum requirements for building design and construction. They cover various aspects of a building's design and construction, including health, safety, aesthetics, and other elements. Green building codes and standards address multiple green building elements, but do not focus solely on energy efficiency. Many jurisdictions adopt national model codes for building regulations. Green building codes go beyond minimum requirements and cover various aspects of building design and construction. Green building codes, also known as "beyond-code" or "above-code" options, exceed minimum building code requirements and specify additional environmental design and performance standards. Governments can choose to make these codes mandatory or voluntary for meeting green building objectives. Voluntary measures for meeting green building objectives often incorporate technical standards created by recognized standards development organizations. These organizations may develop more general green building standards, and buildings meeting these standards can be certified as having met the criteria. Green building standards may be achieved through various pathways, including prescriptive, performance, and outcome-based requirements. These standards are often described as code-intended and aim to certify buildings that meet specific criteria. Green building standards are written in mandatory, code-enforceable language and may be adopted by jurisdictions with modifications. Standards are developed through a consensus process involving multiple stakeholders and require accreditation by bodies like ANSI. Certification must be performed by a third party. The International Code Council (ICC) and ASHRAE are the main developers of national green building model codes and standards in the United States. The ICC is responsible for the widely used International Building Code (IBC) and released the International Green Construction Code (IgCC) in 2012, the first model code to include sustainability measures for entire buildings. The International Green Construction Code (IgCC) was released in 2012 by the ICC, functioning as an overlay code compatible with other ICC codes.
